Pemerintah Tahun Ini Tak Beri Bantuan untuk BPJS Kesehatan
02 Nov 2019, 08:11 by Bisnis.com, Rr. Ariyani Yakti Widyastuti
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Direktur Utama BPJS Kesehatan Fachmi Idris menjelaskan pemerintah mulai tahun ini tidak akan menggelontorkan bantuan langsung berupa dana untuk menutup defisit. Pasalnya, pemerintah telah menyalurkan tambahan dana Anggaran Pendapatan dan Belanja Negara (APBN) seiring naiknya iuran BPJS Kesehatan.
Dana yang dianggarkan itu untuk membiayai selisih kenaikan iuran Penerima Iuran Bantuan (PBI) pada Agustusâ€“Desember 2019 tercatat sekitar Rp 12,7 triliun. Selain itu, ada tambahan dana dari selisih kenaikan iuran segmen Pekerja Penerima Upah (PPU) Pemerintah, yang terdiri dari Aparatur Sipil Negara (ASN), TNI, Polri, dan pegawai Pemerintah Daerah (Pemda).
Adapun besar tambahan dana PPU tersebut berkisar Rp 2 triliun. "Iya, (pada tahun ini) enggak ada suntikan dana. Tahun depan juga enggak ada," ujar Fachmi, Jumat, 1 November 2019.
Pemerintah tercatat memberikan bantuan langsung kepada BPJS Kesehatan mulai 2015. Data Kementerian Keuangan mencatat pemerintah menyalurkan bantuan Rp 5 triliun pada 2015, Rp 6,8 triliun pada 2016, Rp 3,6 triliun pada 2017, dan Rp 10,3 triliun pada 2018.Selain itu, sebenarnya pemerintah masih memberikan subsidi meskipun iuran BPJS Kesehatan telah dinaikkan.
Subsidi tersebut diberikan karena biaya pemanfaatan layanan kesehatan yang sesuai perhitungan baseline masih lebih tinggi dibandingkan dengan besaran iuran yang telah disesuaikan. Fachmi menyebutkan terdapat subsidi Rp 89.195 untuk iuran segmen mandiri kelas 3, Rp 80.639 untuk kelas 2, dan Rp 114.204 untuk kelas 3.
Selisih tersebut disubsidi oleh pemerintah melalui iuran PBI yang nilainya berada di atas baseline. Pada awal 2020, besaran iuran tersebut akan meningkat menjadi Rp 42.000, padahal nilai baseline-nya sebesar Rp 32.451.
"Pemerintah memutuskan iuran di atas perhitungan riil (baseline), pertimbangannya banyak. Presiden tidak menaikkan iuran Pekerja Bukan Penerima Upah (PBPU) sebagaimana seharusnya," ujar Fachmi. Meskipun masih terdapat subsidi, Fachmi menjelaskan penyesuaian iuran merupakan upaya efektif untuk menekan defisit.
Berdasarkan hasil audit Badan Pengawasan Keuangan dan Pembangunan (BPKP), dari berbagai persoalan, akar permasalahan defisit BPJS Kesehatan adalah belum sesuainya besaran iuran dengan perhitungan aktuaria.

This Year The Government Does Not Give Assistance to Health BPJS
02 Nov 2019, 08:11 by Bisnis.com, Rr. Ariyani Yakti Widyastuti
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - BPJS President Director of Health Fachmi Idris explained that the government will not provide direct assistance in the form of funds to cover the deficit this year. Because the government has channeled additional funds to the State Budget (APBN) in line with the increase in BPJS Health contributions.
The budgeted funds to finance the difference in the increase in contribution of Beneficiary Beneficiaries (PBI) in August-December 2019 were recorded around Rp 12.7 trillion. In addition, there are additional funds from the difference between the increase in contribution from the Government Wage Recipient (PPU) segment, which consists of the State Civil Apparatus (ASN), the TNI, Polri, and employees of the Regional Government (Pemda).
The amount of additional PPU funds is around Rp 2 trillion. "Yes, (this year) there is no injection of funds. Next year there will also be no," said Fachmi, Friday, November 1, 2019.
The government has been noted to provide direct assistance to BPJS Health from 2015. Data from the Ministry of Finance noted that the government distributed aid of Rp 5 trillion in 2015, Rp 6.8 trillion in 2016, Rp 3.6 trillion in 2017, and Rp 10.3 trillion in 2018. actually, the government is still providing subsidies even though BPJS Health contributions have been raised.
The subsidy is given because the cost of utilizing health services according to the baseline calculation is still higher than the amount of the adjusted fee. Fachmi said there was a subsidy of Rp 89,195 for class 3 independent segment contributions, Rp 80,639 for class 2, and Rp 114,204 for class 3.
The difference is subsidized by the government through PBI contributions whose values are above the baseline. In early 2020, the contribution rate will increase to Rp 42,000, whereas the baseline value is Rp 32,451.
"The government decided the contribution is above the real calculation (baseline), the consideration is a lot. The president did not increase the contribution of Non Wage Recipients (PBPU) as they should," said Fachmi. Although there are still subsidies, Fachmi explained that adjusting fees is an effective effort to reduce the deficit.
Based on the audit results of the Financial and Development Supervisory Agency (BPKP), from a variety of problems, the root cause of the BPJS Health deficit problem is that the contribution rates have not matched the actuarial calculation.
